docs.snippet: The United States views the proposed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank as a political tool for China to bring countries in Southeast Asia closer to its orbit.
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States views the proposed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank as a political tool for China to bring countries in Southeast Asia closer to its orbit.
docs.abstract: American officials are quietly lobbying against China's plan to form big, internationally funded bank; are engaged in vigorous campaign to persuade important allies, like Australia and South Korea, to shun the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank; United States Treasury Dept has criticized the bank as a deliberate effort to undercut the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

headline.main: U.S. Opposing China’s Answer to World Bank
headline.print_headline: U.S. Opposing China’s Answer to World Bank

docs.abstract: Memo from Seoul; grieving families in Seoul, South Korea, continue their demands for a full inquiry into the April ferry disaster in which 250 high school students died, but Pres Park Geun-hye's conservative supporters have started to criticize them; disaster that initially united country now polarizes it.

headline.main: Ferry Disaster That United South Korea Now Polarizes It
headline.print_headline: Ferry Disaster That United South Korea Now Polarizes It

docs.abstract: Former South Korean intelligence chief Won Sei-hoon is sentenced to two and a half years in prison for violating law that bans his spy agency from involvement in domestic politics.

headline.main: Former South Korean Spy Chief Convicted in Online Campaign Against Liberals
headline.print_headline: South Korea: Spy Chief Is Convicted for Effort to Sway Vote on Social Media

docs.snippet: The artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at an elite he considers responsible for a deadly ferry disaster, and has faced censorship he likens to his treatment during years of dictatorship.
docs.lead_paragraph: The artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at an elite he considers responsible for a deadly ferry disaster, and has faced censorship he likens to his treatment during years of dictatorship.
docs.abstract: South Korean government, in unusual display of censorship, pulls large painting by dissident artist Hong Sung-dam from international art festival; Hong has been outspoken in his opposition to Pres Park Geun-hye's government, echoing widespread criticism of its botched rescue effort following ferry disaster, lax oversight, and resistance to a broad independent investigation.

headline.main: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Korea’s Leader in an Unflattering Light
headline.print_headline: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Korea’s Leader in an Unflattering Light

docs.abstract: South Korea will host the 2018 Olympic Games, but its men’s hockey team may face a daunting road to qualify for the 12-team tournament; there are only 2,100 registered hockey players in South Korea, and although the country has had impressive success at Winter Games, it has never qualified for Olympic hockey.

docs.snippet: Starting on Friday in Incheon, South Korea, athletes will compete in 439 events in 36 sports and disciplines, and the additional content is part of what makes the Asian Games truly Asian.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting on Friday in Incheon, South Korea, athletes will compete in 439 events in 36 sports and disciplines, and the additional content is part of what makes the Asian Games truly Asian.
docs.abstract: Asian Games of 2014 will include kabaddi and sepaktakraw, two sports unfamiliar to the West; kabaddi is a team contact sport developed in and dominated by India; sepaktakraw is a Southeast Asian game dominated by Thailand that combines volleyball and soccer.

headline.main: At the Asian Games, Topsy-Turvy Sports Are Traditional, Too
headline.print_headline: Topsy-Turvy Spectacles Rooted in Tradition

docs.snippet: South Korean education produces ranks of overachieving students who pay a stiff price in health and happiness.
docs.lead_paragraph: South Korean education produces ranks of overachieving students who pay a stiff price in health and happiness.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Se-Woong Koo, editor in chief of website Korea Expose, warns of the amount of stress South Korean students experience as result of an education system that produces ranks of overachievers; contends that South Korea must reform its education system, and cease viewing children as mere cogs in the country's economy with no right to personal happiness.

headline.seo: South Korea’s Education System Hurts Students
headline.main: An Assault Upon Our Children
headline.print_headline: How South Korea Enslaves Its Students
